reviewText:
A very fun RPG, with some collectable card game/Pokemon-esque elements. Specifically, while a few characters join you as you progress through the game, you mostly acquire new characters through in-game lottery machine, and later you can also combine characters with each other or “item” cards to create characters not available otherwise.

Battle are turn-based with both characters acting simultaneously, though different kinds of actions take place in different order, often resulting in one of characters acting before other.  Aside from RPG stats, effectiveness of characters’ attacks is also affected by Rock-Paper-Scissors advantage/disadvantage system – characters and attacks are even marked accordingly!

The main story is short, but fun in a humorous way. And if you enjoy collecting, earning money to “Catch ‘Em All” will add quite the few hours to the gameplay! 200% Mixed Juice also has competitive multiplayer that would put your best characters to the test, and depending on how much you enjoy it, it will give you from several to many hours of fun!

reviewText:
Indie GAGA Review
This is a short review. To view the full review including many more details, a video and screenshots, please follow this link[www.indiegaga.com].


Overview

I must mention first of all that this game primarily serves as a fan service to people who have played other OrangeJuice titles. This is a JRPG with strong visual novel elements. Our first introduction to the characters in this was from 100% Orange Juice (a virtual board game) which was a little confusing if you think of it like playing Mario Party alone. You see, the Japanese were introduced to the characters through OrangeJuice's bullet hell games, so they already knew who many of the characters were. You might think of this as unimportant, but really, you will be lost when playing this if you haven't played any of the other OrangeJuice titles.

Dialogue is childish, and so is the humour, so don't expect anything serious. Battles are fought with a perspective highly similar to Pokémon. Like 100% Orange Juice, you work with cards. You can collect an endless number of cards, but you can choose three to fight with. Each card is a character with its own attacks. (There are item cards, but these come into gameplay later on.) You can choose from rock, paper and scissors, and these will determine your strength and defence. If you find yourself at a disadvantage you can switch cards. Attacks have different SP costs, which you gain through dice rolls at the start of turns. Battles are fun, but grinding isn't.

Honestly, the story is a bit half-♥♥♥♥♥ and corny, but when you consider the game as fan service and not taking itself seriously, it's forgivable. I wouldn't recommend it to those unfamiliar with the franchises. The developers tried hard to give the game a retro look, similar to 16-bit games, and they did a good job. In my experience it screws the screen up in full-screen mode, so I played windowed. I hope the devs fix this. Music is mostly sub-par, with some nice tracks. I can't judge the online mode yet, but I'll update the review when I can.


Ratings

CategoryScoreExplanationGameplay7/10It's easy to learn, perhaps too easy though. Those familiar with Pokémon should like the battle system. Sadly, you'll have to grind a lot. Card collection is fun, but cards are unbalanced. You can skip through cutscenes. Online play is a nice addition that I'll add to the review.Story4.5/10The script might be annoying to those who prefer serious JRPGs. However, the humour is light-hearted with memes included every so often and fourth wall breaking.Graphics4.5/10Art is of good quality, but all frames are static. The game is a cheap purchase, though. Backgrounds are a little too pixelated. Full-screen problems need fixing.Sound6/10Along with the graphics, the music has a retro quality, being chiptune. Most of the music is very average, but some of the boss themes are great.

Final Verdict

6/10

reviewText:
So what do we have here?Well, as most reviews will tell you, we have the 10 years anniversary game for the Orange_Jucie Devs, where they have (somewhat) stepped out of their comfort zone of bullet hell arcade shooters into the work of an RPG game with battle mechanics that resemble Pokemon crossed in with Rock, Paper Sciciors, the real question would be, did it work?

Did it work?Yes and no, The game is simple and seems not too in depth. The mechanics work and get the job done but are not too well highlighted (Speed seems to increase dodge chance, while who hits first is on a tiered system of Close Combat<Multi Shot<Single shot) that, if explained was missed by my dumb face. Obtaining characters is total RNG and fusing characters is very select and late game pretty much before the final boss.

How long is it?200% Mixed Juice is a short game, you should have the main plot done in around 4 hours or less, and with a guide, be able to get all the achievements in around 5. It has some replayability with multiplayer, and a final challenge of facing the last boss again but harder. So in all, the game is short, which is not always a bad thing, not outstaying it's welcome.

Is it FUN?!?This is perhaps the most important question, is the game fun? I will say that I personally found it enjoyable, mucking around a little in multi player, the characters are silly and so is the game. Everything about this game was designed to be silly from the ground up. It's no epic plot from Final Fantasy, and nor should it be it's a quick little game with heart and solid mechanics.

GripesNot everything about this game is perfect, and as of writing this, mouse support would be nice, while keyboard functions. Getting characters is VERY RNG for those who wish to 'catch em all'. And, It would be nice to be able to speed up battles when grinding (Which is needed for the final boss). The Artwork on characters is not the best, and at times, plain ugly and lazy,

Do I suggest it?Do you like RPG's? Silly characters and/or Orange_Juice Titles? Then yes, yes I would. If you're looking for an in depth world, filled with deep story, heartfelt connections and something to sink a huge amount of time in? No, this is not your game.
But at $8.59(NZD) You can do worse, so for a fun afternoon when you have some time to kill, playing 200% Mixed Juice might just scratch that RPG itch, and perhaps give you a smile.

reviewText:
This is a light-hearted RPG with fun battles, while there are a few flaws, I would definitely recommend it. The battles might seems random at first, with SP, which is the game's equivalent of energy which is used for using moves, being rolled at the start of the turn, but after that damage rolls are rather consistent outside of critical hits, and the odds are against people using strategies which inflict nasty statuses such as immobilization. There are only three 'elements' in the game, which work like rock-paper-scisssors, however, most of your cards are in no way restricted to only their own element when attacking.

The story is light-hearted and somewhat similar to the stories you might find in most bullet hell games in that most of the time you fight with the people you meet but then you become friends. The game does occasionally break the fourth wall but it never does so too much. The game is loaded with references to other Orange_Juice games but the story should be enjoyable even for people who haven't played any other Orange_Juice game. The story is clever in that it does hint towards what will end up happening, which is especially prominent when going through the story a second time.

Unlike 100% Orange Juice you can't really just go into multiplayer from the start since your cards do have levels and need to be leveled up in the story even though the game features ways of restricting which cards are pickable in a match. To get through the story mode you do need to do a little grinding, but that is to be expected from an old school RPG. Sadly the multiplayer isn't flourishing at the moment, and the game lacks a way of spectating a match, this is definitely something the developers could expand upon, by for example adding spectating and mayhap introducing double battles, like in pokémon.

In the end the game is definitely worth it for the low price.

reviewText:
200% Mixed Juice is basically a amalgamation of EVERY game made by Orange juice, in an RPG based format. This DOES mean that there are a lot of references to other games, but I still think it works as a standalone game nonetheless.

The gameplay works in a rock/paper/scissors fashion, but it also has another rock/paper/scissors mechanic within this that people don't seem to get. So each character has an attribute, be it rock paper or scissors. Each attack also has an attribute. The ORDER of attack is based on the attributes of the ATTACKS, not the characters. So if I were to use a rock attack and you were to use a paper attack, you would have priority regardless of the attribute of our respective characters. This adds a decent amount of depth into the gameplay, since the choice between doing more damage and priority can be difficult. The fact that there is no real tutorial for this mechanic is met with criticism, but meh, I figured it out eventually.

The main game has over 50 character cards, so it's fair to say that there's a LOT of choice, and therefore replayability value. I think of it akin to the likes of Pokemon, each time you play through it's different each time, since your choices are extremely varied.

The graphics are an issue met with a lot of debate for this game. They're meant with a old school RPG theme in mind, so we can't judge them on being 'too pixelated' etc. To me they actually suit the game pretty well, I never thought that an area looked particularly ugly or unsightly. Either way I never think we should judge a game by graphics alone but hey, each to their own I guess.

The music though... It is very impressive. They use a chiptune style, fitting in with the old school RPG idea and it works very well for the game as a whole. Each track is a joy to listen to and there are a few boss tracks that particularly stand out to me at least.

The story is about 5-6 hrs long, so not an extremely lengthy game. There seems to be a lot of going back and forth between humour and seriousness, but I like that about it. There is a sense of urgency but no real stress due to the interactions between characters, you get groped at one point... Which for some reason I find particularly funny. (Help, I'm a terrible person)

There's a multiplayer arena also for PvP which is pretty fun when you have a team set up. You'll always meet people with a team full of OP characters but to be fair I've beat them with ease... They often use the same attributes and have no idea of game mechanics, so you'll be fine if you have a decent coverage of types.

In conclusion, 200% Mixed Juice is a very quirky RPG which is a must have for anyone who has played the OJ games, and still a very good game for those who haven't. It has a very good style and sticks to it, which I can appreciate. The gameplay is simple yet complex depending on how deep you want to go, and all in all is just a very solid game, especially for the low price it's selling for

reviewText:
I am making this an honest review, from someone who is  a mix between a casual and hard-core gamer.

I was excited for this game since it was announced even after seeing the screenshots but was worried I would find it hard due to the mighty RNG of 100% Orange Juice but he doesn't seem to be in this game so lucky us.

It didn't take me long to complete the game's story, it is only hard if you forgot what type the enemy is if you know what type they are then you know who to bring out to make it a cake-walk. You can easily win the game using the three character's you befriend within the game.
This game needs a little bit of grinding but once you know which path you can keep re-visiting and beating with ease, grinding to defeat the current world boss should not take no longer than 10-30 minutes.


It has a nice fusion gimmick but getting some of the items to fuse some characters is a chore sad to say even if you are grinding your extra cards to max card level you can still struggle to find certain items making it a chore than fun.

My only frustration with this game would be the card-collecting and the lack of guidence to which cards you are missing and the massive chance of getting duplicates.
The post-game is pretty much for collectors, those wanting every single card combination there is and there is no guidence in which cards you need or what fusions you can get.

--------------------------
Pros

- Simple fighting mechanic (easy for anyone to pick up)
- Funny story
- Lots of familiar characters to collect
- Simple story to follow
- Chibi characters

Cons

- Too much grinding after-game to get all the cards
- Too many chances to get duplicate cards
- Multiplayer is boring and plain
- Without a guide you are guessing card-fusions
- No guide to which cards you are missing

----------------------
Nitpicks
- Menu screens have terrible graphics when when the chibi characters pop out, after a while it becomes a pain to look at
- Only 1-2 songs in the game which get boring real fast
- Not much of post-game reward but more cards to grind for
- You will die in 1-2 turns unless you grind, making boost" attacks worthless
- Many characters share the same attack
- Evade never seems to work making it useless



If you are a fan of Orange Juice

reviewText:
A pokemon-like RPG that lacks what made Pokemon great.

The battle mechanics are shallow, not particularly unique, and overall just kinda boring. I found myself wanting to push on not because I found the game fun, but because I wanted to just get it over with already. That's not a good feeling for a game to have.

There's also not any real difficulty other than RNG and forced grinding. The campaign is pretty short, and would be even shorter if it didn't force you to level grind -a lot- before bosses (the final boss in particular).

Status effects, unlike Pokemon, can't really be dealt with in any way. If you're paralyzed, you can't even switch out - you basically have to watch as the opponent beats up on your character for several turns. On top of that, there's only one type - immobilization/paralysis. And it's boring.

I really wanted to like this game. I love Orange Juice. They made Sora, one of my favorite video games of all time. This may actually be the first bad game they've produced.

If you buy this game expecting the fun and longevity of 100% Orange Juice, or the genius game design of Sora, you will be sorely disappointed. Keep in mind - this is OJ's first venture into the RPG genre, so you can't expect perfection, but... It lacks the things that make RPGs good. The only real reasons to get this game are the 100%OJ character that comes with it and the opportunity to learn a little bit more about OJ's characters.

reviewText:
To be honest this is an amazing game. It is, to put it simpaly a 'mix' of all of Orange_Juice's characters (Hence the name) it is rather comedic all most with out even trying. But it has a few glitches and problems... by a few I mean one. The only glitch I've found is if you Alt+Tab out during a battle the game will crash. *Dog jumps on lap during final boss fight, presses windows button by mestake... game crashes.* And the problem with the game is mainly to get some jokes or references you need to of played 100% orange juice or other Orange_Juice games (I may as well add that this was the first Orange_Juice game I played) but after playing QP Shooting I got some of the references but not all of them.
Still back to this game.
The battles are fun and sought of remind me of playing Pokemon among other things, other people have said it reminds them of playing other JRPG's but for some reason Pokemon stood out for me... odd thing to say I know.
The game is rather short (It took me about 6 hours including grinding) after words I tried to speed run the game with my level cap characters and skipping all the text between fights and I got through most of the game in about 50 min... short a'int it. THe game has a seamingly empty multiplayer feature. (Still havn't worked out how to get a ramdom battle)
The system of buying cards eventually gets kinda bull. (While looking for a certain item I got the rarest item in the game... twice... and the item I was looking for was only labeled 'Rare')
There is a system of mixing characters is quite funny when it's first introduced. (The machine that mixes charactors is described as a giant juicer) but eventually becomes an essential game element as some charactors, even at level cap are kinda... ♥♥♥♥.
So. Let's talk story.
'Awaken sleeping princess'
'Wake up sleepy head princess or I will die of boredom' (Oh really?)
Apart from the braketed part these are lines from the fist few lines of the game.
You are told that the person who woke you 'Navi' has gone and made a 'small' world... that seems to consist of three seperate worlds... okay. you are given a name 'Protagionest' (I don't know if I spelt that right) oh and I'm not kidding about the name either. you are told that from being asleep for so long your social skills have degraded completely. Probably why for most of the game you're mute. At least the reason you're mute is explained. Anyway.
At the second last fight in the game you fight yourself... WTF. characters constantly break the forth wall one character even goes as far to admit to this fact.
So let's quickly recap before I lose my mind.
Great game, short but in a good way, (Portal one style) story that seems to be rather generic at first glance but when you delve into it the game become a unique jewel full of non-standered humour and lots of forth wall breaking. The odd glitch and dog caused crash and a need to know other games to get some joke/refencences.
The game ends on the cliff hanger from hell and after finishing it four or five times I still know nothing of it. I guess I'll do some searching of the interwebs to find out atleast something... probably be the best way to spend the rest of my weekend.
It's quite cheap so if you are in for a stupidly comedic adventure or for a good RPG give this game a try.
Oh and the charactors look quite cute... so yeah give it a go.
